steps.title: Open Excel.
steps.content: Open Excel. It's a green app with a white "X" on it. You'll need to click Blank workbook (PC) or New and then Blank Workbook (Mac) to continue. If you have an existing presentation you'd like to open, double-click it to open it in Excel.

steps.title: Click a cell.
steps.content: Click a cell. Doing so will select it, allowing you to type into it.

steps.title: Type = into the cell.
steps.content: Type = into the cell. All formulas in Excel start with the equals sign.

steps.title: Enter the first number.
steps.content: Enter the first number. This should go directly after the "=" symbol with no space. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Type * after the first number.
steps.content: Type * after the first number. The asterisk symbol indicates that you wish to multiply the number before the asterisk with the number that comes after it. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Enter the second number.
steps.content: Enter the second number. For example, if you first entered a 6, and wanted to multiply it by 6, your formula would now look like =6*6 . [3] X Research source You can repeat this process with as many numbers as you like, as long as the "*" symbol is between each of the numbers you want to multiply.

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter . This will run your formula. The cell will display the product of the formula, though clicking the cell will display the formula itself in the Excel address bar. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Open an Excel presentation.
steps.content: Open an Excel presentation. Simply double-click an Excel document to open it in Excel.

steps.title: Click a cell.
steps.content: Click a cell. Doing so will select it, allowing you to type into it.

steps.title: Type = into the cell.
steps.content: Type = into the cell. All formulas in Excel start with the equals sign.

steps.title: Type in another cell's name.
steps.content: Type in another cell's name. This should go directly after the "=" with no space. For example, typing "A1" into the cell sets A1's value as the first number in your formula.

steps.title: Type * after the first cell name.
steps.content: Type * after the first cell name. The asterisk symbol indicates to Excel that you want to multiply the value before it with the value after it. [5] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Type in a different cell's name.
steps.content: Type in a different cell's name. This will set the second variable in your formula as the second cell's value. [6] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source For example, typing "D5" into the cell would make your formula look like this: =A1*D5 . You can add more than two cell names to this formula, though you'll need to type "*" between subsequent cell names.

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter . This will run your formula and display the result in your selected cell. When you click the cell with the formula result, the formula itself will display in the Excel address bar.

steps.title: Open an Excel presentation.
steps.content: Open an Excel presentation. Simply double-click an Excel document to open it in Excel.

steps.title: Click a cell.
steps.content: Click a cell. Doing so will select it, allowing you to type into it. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Type =PRODUCT( into your cell.
steps.content: Type =PRODUCT( into your cell. This command indicates that you want to multiply items together.

steps.title: Type in the first cell's name.
steps.content: Type in the first cell's name. This should be the cell at the top of the range of data. For example, you might type "A1" here.

steps.title: Type :
steps.content: Type : . The colon symbol (":") indicates to Excel that you want to multiply everything from the first cell through the next cell you enter. [8] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source

steps.title: Type in another cell's name.
steps.content: Type in another cell's name. This cell must be in the same column or row as the first cell in the formula if you want to multiply all the cells from the first cell to this one. In the example, typing "A5" would set up the formula to multiply the contents of A1, A2, A3, A4, and A5 together.

steps.title: Type ), then press ↵ Enter.
steps.content: Type ) , then press ↵ Enter . This last parenthesis closes the formula, and hitting enter runs the command and multiplies your range of cells together, displaying the result instantly in your selected cell. If you change the contents of a cell within the multiplication range, the value in your selected cell will also change.
